xxl.core.cursors.sources.io
Class FileNameCursor

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<String>
      xxl.core.cursors.sources.io.FileNameCursor
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator<String>, Cursor<String>
public class FileNameCursor
extends AbstractCursor<String>

This class provides an implementation of the cursor interface that iterates over the files contained in the specified path and its subdirectories and returns their names. The names are given relative to the specified path.

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor

Constructor Detail

FileNameCursor

public FileNameCursor(File path,
                      FileFilter fileFilter)
Creates a new file-name cursor that iterates over the files contained in the specified path. The specified file filter decides, which files should be returned and which subdirectories should be searched.

Parameters:
path - the directory to search for files.
fileFilter - the file filter that decides which files should be returned and which subdirectories should be searched.

FileNameCursor

public FileNameCursor(String path,
                      FileFilter fileFilter)
Creates a new file-name cursor that iterates over the files contained in the specified path. The specified file filter decides, which files should be returned and which subdirectories should be searched. The path is not allowed to contain wildcards (it must be a valid directory, i.e., ".").

Parameters:
path - the directory to search for files.
fileFilter - the file filter that decides which files should be returned and which subdirectories should be searched.

FileNameCursor

public FileNameCursor(File path,
                      boolean recursive)
Creates a new file-name cursor that iterates over the files contained in the specified path. The specified boolean flag decides whether subdirectories should be searched recursively.

Parameters:
path - the path to search for files.
recursive - decides whether the cursor should search for files in subdirectories.

FileNameCursor

public FileNameCursor(String path,
                      boolean recursive)
Creates a new file-name cursor that iterates over the files contained in the specified path. The specified boolean flag decides whether subdirectories should be searched recursively. The path is not allowed to contain wildcards (it must be a valid directory, i.e., ".").

Parameters:
path - the path to search for files.
recursive - decides whether the cursor should search for files in subdirectories.

Parameters:

Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the file-name cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open files, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor<String>
Overrides:
open in class AbstractCursor<String>

close

public void close()
Closes the file-name cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close files, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor<String>
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor<String>

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<String>
Returns:
true if the file-name cursor has more elements.

nextObject

protected String nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the file-name cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<String>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the file-name cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation).

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<String>
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor<String>
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the file-name cursor.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the file-name cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor<String>
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<String>
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the file-name cursor, otherwise false.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
